Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Story: It’s Saturday afternoon, and my phone buzzes with a message from Mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend! Call us when you can.” I glance at the clock—my team’s weekly catch-up meeting starts in ten minutes. I know the meeting will be recorded, and it’s not urgent, but I also know my manager expects everyone to show up and contribute, even if it’s just routine. At the same time, I haven’t spoken to my parents all week, and I can almost hear the disappointment in Mom’s voice if I put off calling again. I feel the weight of both expectations pressing on me: my parents want to feel connected, to know I’m okay, while my team expects me to be present and engaged. I stare at my phone, torn between dialing home and logging into Zoom, my mind racing with guilt and anxiety, wishing I could be in two places at once.
